channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: Video game company Electronic Arts confirmed plans for a historic deal
item.description: NPR's Scott Detrow talks with Jennifer Maas, a senior business writer at Variety, about video game company Electronic Arts' agreement to be acquired and taken private in a deal valued at $55 billion.

item.title: A preview of the MLB playoffs
item.description: Baseball playoffs begin Tuesday with some familiar teams: the New York Yankees, Boston Red Sox and LA Dodgers. But the San Diego Padres, Chicago Cubs, Detroit Tigers and Cleveland Guardians are back.

item.title: Tyler Robinson's team requests time to review evidence in his second court appearance
item.description: The defense for Tyler Robinson, the suspect in the Charlie Kirk assassination, has asked for more time to review the evidence before deciding whether to seek a preliminary hearing.

item.title: You can't come to the touring Cake Picnic unless you bring a dessert to share
item.description: People across Southern California came out to eat cake this weekend… 483 different cakes to be exact. A touring picnic took over a Santa Monica park with one simple rule…bring a cake.

item.title: Unlocking the Gen Z consumer
item.description: As Nike targets a new generation with a revised slogan, "Why Do It?," NPR's Ailsa Chang talks to consumer trends expert Casey Lewis about what brands get right and wrong about Gen Z.

item.title: Congressional leaders met with President Trump ahead of shutdown deadline
item.description: The federal government is close to a shutdown. President Trump met Monday with top Congressional leaders from both parties in the Oval Office, which ended with both sides dug in.

item.title: The future of public media in South Dakota
item.description: With federal funding ending later this week, our media correspondent went to South Dakota to learn what people want from public media today.

item.title: Russell M. Nelson, head of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, dies at 101
item.description: The leader of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints has died. Russell M. Nelson was 101 years old — the oldest person to have ever led the Salt Lake City-based faith.

item.title: With no guarantee of U.S. weapons, Ukraine races to make its own
item.description: President Trump says the U.S. won't be giving more weapons to Ukraine. As a result, Ukraine is racing to make as many of its own weapons as it can.

item.title: A ubiquitous flower in LA brings memories of homeland for a local Salvadoran chef
item.description: At this time of year, the flor de izote, or yucca flower, blooms in Los Angeles. Chef Karla Vasquez bought some at a Salvadoran market, and prepared a recipe from her book The Salvisoul Cookbook.
